title: Which are the saddest violin and piano pieces ever? - Quora

response.answer_text: Samuel Osborne Barber’s Adagio for Strings has to be the saddest piece I’ve ever come across, classical or otherwise. I don’t believe Barber could have expressed such sadness without having had firsthand experience of it or maybe he could empathize with pure melancholy just as well as he could compose. Whatever it was, it made me empathize with the sorrow that he poured into the making of this piece and he achieved that without the use of lyrics. This piece rouses in me a longing that’s been kept suppressed all my adult life; a longing for the memory of a past when it was all so much simpler. I found myself remembering happy fragments of my childhood that I didn’t know even existed in my memory. What followed was a fleeting atmosphere shift to the utopia that once was my life and what followed that was the regret that the feeling was all too short. I’ve learnt to use such ‘Portkeys’ sparingly because I know the more I’d listen to that piece the more it’d morph into my present life and out of the one I once had. And were that to happen, I’d no longer have a telescope, if you will, into my past other than my faulty and often distortive memory.

I'd like this to be played at my funeral - Tomasso Vitali's Chaconne. This is approximately 300 years old, Baroque, but so beautiful. This is so amazingly poignant, especially when Oistrakh played it on his Strad.
